The set of clay pipes become a gift as a gesture of opening night! This auctioneer is a man who puts his words into auction. The vision he had twelve years ago for operating his own auction has Blossomed in a new enterprise, THE PAMPLIN CLAY PIPE FAC TORY AND AUCTION. The auctioneer is none other than Raymond D ickerosn, dreamer, founder, builder and operator of a fascinating new venture that has come to Pamplin City. Raymond Dickerson, knoura to many as THE PIPE MAN, is a man with vision and sharp determination. Twelve years ago a clay pipe was accidental ly found at the present site of the Pamplin Clay Pipe Factory. No one could have knowm that twelve years later the ruins of the pipe factory would be what it has become today, i  Most people who passed the min a of the decayed pipe factory and kiln day in and day out saw only an eyesore. But one man looked through those ruins and saw something that no one else saw. He had a vision of reopening the day pipe factory and turning what used to be a community eyesore into a business of interest for everyone. July 1 marked the opening of the PIPE MAN AUCTION. document.text: Researchers know that pipe manu facture existed as a cottage industry or home industry, long before the pipe factory was built, and possibly as far back as the early 1700s. There is also some evidence that a clay-pipe factory existed on the Dickerson property before 1879, but lack of records due to a fire at the county courthouse during that period of time has made this supposition difficult to substantiate. Dickerson and his wife, Nancy decided that the Pamplin clay pipe factory, falling into disrepair by the rnmmnmim fcr history Which should be. preserved. Thus, in 1976, they purchased the property from Charlie Ranson, and began restoring the structures which had once - housed the largest manufacturer of clay pipes in the United States.- . It wasnt easy. Dickerson recalls fighting rats and snakes, vandals, and jungle-like weeds that had cropped up around the factory since the business had closed down. But the Dickersons perserverance was greater than the forces of nature, and in July of 1978 the museum opened.  The original kiln, which in its heyday could hold as many as 200,000 clay pipes at one time, still stands on the museum grounds. The kilns chimney fell several years ago after continued abuse by vandals and Mother Nature. Im hoping to instore the chimney. says Dickerson. There is a chance t hat the property will be eligible for federal funding assistance if its nomination to the National Register of Historic Places is approved!  Dickerson hopes that he will be able to get some of this money to restore the chimney. Other than the possibility of federal funding to help restore the chimney, the most important thing about the historic landmarks designation to Dickerson is the recognition for Pamplin. Pamplin is a lovely place, says Dickerson. But in the last part of this century, its dried up. Theres so much history wrapped up in this town and in these clay pipes, history that involves the whole country? and the whold world. Something like that should be preserved, and hopefully in preserving it, we can contribute to the preservation of Pamplin. New principal at AES

document.text: In d u s trie s For many years there were practically no industries in the County, except some saw-mills, grist and four mills, and a urnace operated in Stonewall District, near James River, which suspended operation in 1850. In the year 1879, Merrill  Ford established a clay smoking pipe factory at Pamplin, and operated the same for a ong time, manufacturing clay smoking pipes, giving employ ment to a small number of people in that section. This com pany is still being operated in a small way. Of late years, through the efforts of our people, there have been secured and established some small industries in our County, including two garment factories, three lumber yards and mills, a battery fac tory, a milk plant, and a box factory, the latter, being a War Defense Plant, all of which give employment to quite a number of our people and are contributing materially to the develop ment of our County. Appomattox and Pamplin, with their motor companies and numerous stores, are trading centers, contributing ma terially to the progress and development of the County.

He has written a book about the art of  clay pipe manufacture, questioned hundreds of Pamplin-area residents about the Pamplii clay pipe, and studiously researcher-archives and literature about the clay pipe. The Pamplin clay pipe factory was in full operation from 1879 until 1951, producing at its peak as many as a million pipes per month. The original factory was built by an Ohio firm specializing in pipes. The Pamplin location was chosen because the clay in that area was ideal for making pipes. ArefMnafogisfo have determined that at one point, the Pamplin factory was the largest industry of its type inr the nation, and possibly in the world..

document.text: Pamplin is a small town, basically just like thousands of others scattered across the United States. Its people are no diffent. Its trade is essentially the same. In bet, the only thing that distinguish es Pamplin from any other rural town is its 200 year old pipe factory. Legend has it the first settlers of the Pamplin area learned the art of pipemaking from local Indians. Orginally the pipes were made soley for relaxation and pleasure. In later times, especially during the Civil War, the pipes came to play a vital role in the survival of num erous low income families. The women and children made the pipes by hand in their backyards and sold them to local stores while their men fought in the war. Little did they know that their pipes were the beginnings of an industry that would one day claim to be the worlds sole producer of genuine Indian pipes. The home industrys process was really quite simple. They nearly merely mixed the clay with water to create the right texture, rolled it into the shape of a cigar, and placed it in the closed mold. Then the bowl- reamer tool, sometimes called a bowl stick was forced down into the bowl with a rotaing motion until the excess day was pushed into the shank. The shank stick was then inserted in the same way and removed. With the bowl stick still in place, the mold was opened and the pipe removed. The rough edges of the pipe w ere smoothed Out with..a hooked scraper. A small wire was pushed through the shank into the bottom of the bowl to provide a hole for drawing

However, according to a letterhead, the Pamplin Smoking Pipe and Manufacturing Co., Inc. was established in 1739. With it came molds of elaborate design which gradually grew in number. It was not long before the Pamplin Smoking Pipe and Manufacturing Co., Inc. was recognized as being the largest clay pipe factory in the United States. But, times change and they will. Due to the World War II the market weakened and planned overseas shipments stopped. In the early 1940s the company was forced to dose down. The pipes that wore ready for shipm ent w ere buried somewhere near the factory. It wasnt until liU years later that large quanity was unearthed by aeddent. Since then several thousand have been sold to the Eastern National Park and Monument Association. The remainder of the pipes will probably be sold to local gift shops or private collectors. And, if present conditions persist, the old historical factory will be torn down and Pamplin will become just another town.
